course.subject: HUMA
course.name: Human Culture and Society
course.description: An introduction to concepts and principles of human cultures and societies from the anthropological perspective, exploring the interaction between culture and society and the causes underlying their changes.

reviews.author: Kabul
reviews.title: A lot of writing throughout the semester
reviews.comment_content:
An introductory course to anthropology. It starts with a brief introduction to the anthropological "mindset", then moves to how we can analyze cultures in different dimensions. The way Prof Liu approaches anthropology seems quite different from the previous professor - instead of focusing on historical and socio-political issues, she digs into minor stuff around our daily lives we've usually taken for granted, and drills very deeply into specific examples. These really challenge what we have in mind and rewind our "it-has-to-be-like-this" way of thinking. Overall this is one of the very few courses in UST that can help us "unlearn" things and become open-minded towards things that just don't work as we think.

Course Intended Learning Outcomes (ILOs): (quoted from the course syllabus)
1Ô∏è‚É£ Understand basic terms, concepts, and theories in cultural anthropology about human culture
and society.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Develop an appreciation of cultural diversity and understand the meanings of different
cultural practices in their socio-cultural contexts.
3Ô∏è‚É£ Develop ethnographic research skills for collecting field data on human culture and society.

Like what is said in other reviews, the content could be interesting, but could also be boring to those who aren't really into HUMA courses - I think most of us only take this course to fulfill the common core requirements. It's indeed worth a try if you wanna taste a new perspective of thinking about things in our daily lives, but think twice before registering this course if what you want is only easy good grade. It'll be hard if you can't grasp what the point of discussion is.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Liu really inspires us in her lectures. She illustrates numerous examples that deviate from our daily experience to showcase the beauty of cultural diversity. She also engages us in the tutorial discussion - but it ends up with endless chitchatting in our group LOL.

No laptops, no phones, no chatting on her lectures.

reviews.comment_workload:
IMHO quite heavy for a 1000-level course.

There are a total of 9 tutorial assignments out of which 8 will be taken into the calculation of your grade. It's really a lot compared to other courses. The professor said it should be a piece of cake for us - but I don't think it is. The thing is that the assignments are due BEFORE the related content is even taught. I can't get the point of doing so. Maybe the tutorial assignments are intended to prepare us for the lectures - but as it turns out most of us get confused when doing the assignments.

There are assigned readings every lecture flooded with difficult vocab and complicated sentence structures that will puzzle you. I'm a year-3 student and I gave up after reading a couple of them - but the prof said this course was designed for year-1 students üòµ. Attached is one of the assigned readings. Have a look.

The norm violation project is a tough one. We're required to ideate and conduct a norm-violating social experiment, write a 6-page ethnographic essay on our observations and analyze the situation from an anthropological perspective. But we are never taught how to write a good ethnographical essay and we have little idea of what is exactly expected in the writing. Though the TAs have given us some advice on the writing, I believe most of us still remain puzzled.

The final is a take-home exam with 4 short questions and 2 long essays based on the lectures and the assigned readings. We are given 3 days to complete it. Attached are the take-home exam questions. Take a look.

(Since it's a take-home exam directly available on Canvas I think it's fine to post it here.)

reviews.author: Annnnndy
reviews.title: Interesting common core course
reviews.comment_content:
The title of this course is ‚ÄúHuman Culture and Society‚Äù and Prof Liu said she prepared the course for ‚Äúfreshmen‚Äù as an introduction of anthropology at the beginning of the semester. Content is really interesting because it`s tried to train students to think in the anthropology way and look the world in different angles. By thinking like an anthropologist, students can understand and explain those ‚Äústrange and unacceptable‚Äù behavior or custom of foreign culture.

I attached the course syllabus below for whom may be interested.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Liu printed the handout of each lecture by herself for students to take away. I can tell that she was well prepared for each lecture as she presented the teaching content clearly and won`t make students feel so boring.
Tutorial sessions were set up for students to exchange ideas and gain from each others. I`d say the purpose was achieved to some extent and I make a friend from my assigned group mates but sometimes I still feel it can be improved.
reviews.comment_grading:
36% Norm Violation Essay
40% Final Take-home Exam
24% Tutorial Assignments

34/36 for norm violation essay, 21/24 for tutorial assignments and Prof Liu gave final grade without releasing the final take-home exam grade.
Final grade: B+

It`s a bit disappointing but I guess I screwed up the final exam??
reviews.comment_workload:
One tutorial assignment for a week in average (nine in total and count eight of them in your grade), an essay equivalent to the midterm exam and a final take-home exam you can write for three days formed the grade-direct-relating workload. There are also exist 18 readings in the course to discuss in the tutorials and may contribute in the final exam.
Overall, I think the workload is acceptable but not that appropriate.

reviews.author: Cici Ho
reviews.title: Interesting course with good grades
reviews.comment_content: Content details are mentioned in the previous reviews so check them out. You can learn a lot about different cultures and the reason behind their formation. There are a lot of real life examples illustrating the concepts and almost everyone can understand them. Overall, the course is easy to understand and are interesting.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Liu is Taiwanese, she speaks with some accents but understanding them is not difficult. She is good at explaining the materials and inspire students to think more. As she mentioned, the course won't provide us the answer, but to provide us the method of anthropological thinking. The TAs always answer emails prompt, and are ready for assistance. Lectures and tutorials are more or less the same as they take place together in 1.5 hr.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is really good.
My mid-term essay (31/36) is below mean (33/36). Tutorial assignment almost full mark (2.9/3  x 8)
The final exam is unknown.

Final grade: A
pretty good grade since I just first study huma course.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is not heavy if you do the reading materials regularly since you may then need to cram during the exam period. There are 10 tutorial assignment which they count 8 highest mark (actually everyone can get 2.9/3 if you write enough words so they are pretty easy! make sure you hand them in even you skip lectures!)
Originally, there's no attendance taking in tutorials. But hanks to the guys who sent emails to prof. and demanded credits for hardworking students lol. Mid-term essay is easy as well which only takes me two days to finish. Be careful for the final exam. Though 3 days are given, your exam may take place during that time, so make sure you read all the materials before the exam if you want an A.

reviews.author: katy19
reviews.comment_content:
Course Description:
Anthropology is a discipline concerned with what it means to be human; we research ‚Äúhumanity‚Äù
through exotically foreign human practices no less than through those human practices that are
most familiar to us. It provides a way of seeing the world and the place(s) of humanity in it that
emphasizes holism, experiential learning, and comparison. Anthropology is as concerned with
understanding the differences between and within groups of people as it is with the similarities
that make all of us equally human. Moreover, it offers a perspective on difference that allows us
to see how some differences have been historically infused with power, resulting not just in
difference, but deep-seated inequalities. This course introduces students to the core questions,
conversations, and concepts that have driven anthropological research and whose discussions have
provided valuable insight into the human experience.

reviews.author: Thomasboy368
reviews.title: Great Course
reviews.comment_content:
The contents are very good for those who would like to study Human Culture. They are about Feminism, Muslims and Hong Kong history etc.
If you are not interested in HUMA, you can do your things during lessons. He doesn't care.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. HA has a really great accent and good voice. He also has a great sense of humour. He would like to discuss with students. He can provide insight and provoke us to deep thinking.

Reading materials. It is your choice to read or not. You won't receive any punishment if u didn't read.
reviews.comment_grading:
Attendance (10% You can skip 3 lessons without receiving a grade penalty.)
Photo Essay 30%
Short film 30%
Essay 30%

It is so easy to get a good grade.
I got 27/30(photo essay), 30/30( short film), 29/30 (essay)

I got A+ at the end without pressure.
reviews.comment_workload:
not really, the assignments are very easy. Only 3 assignments.
The photo essay is about 10-20 photos about the human social culture topic that u chose.
The Short film is about 1:30-3 mins long about the human social culture topic that u chose.
The essay is about 600 words about the human social culture topic that u chose.

The topic of 3 assignments must be the same.

reviews.author: Bala
reviews.comment_content: The course was about the anthropological study of human culture and society. Most of the topics included were very interesting, however a few of them can be pretty boring.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor was very helpful and tried his best to engage students during the class. He explained the topics well and encouraged the students to share their opinions in class.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading for the course was pretty lenient in my opinion.
30% for photo essay
30% for short movie
30% for final essay
10% attendance

All 3 of the topics are individual work and you have free reign over which topics you want to choose.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload for the course is manageable. There are readings assigned every week however most of the students did not really bother with them as they are not related to the assignments and you can follow with the lecture even if you did not read them.

reviews.author: huich
reviews.comment_content: Anthropological study of human culture and society. The course was mainly about histories of colonialism, patriarchy, global capitalism, political oppression and social exclusion. The content was quite interesting but some can find it boring.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lecturer was quite humorous and tries to engage the class with thoughtful discussions on topics. He responds well to students' queries.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading for this course was fantastic. I would say the lecturer gives out decent grades to most.

Course Assessment:
10% Attendance
30% Photo Essay (Mean: 25.7/30)
30% Short Film and Presentation (Mean: 26/30)
30% Final Essay (Mean: 26.2/30)

I got 29/30 for all three assignments with full attendance. My final grade was A+.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was light. There were assigned readings each week but no students read them because you do not need them for your assignments. You don't even have to relate your assignments to the topics he discussed on in the lectures if you wish, but it should still relate to human culture and society. The assignments do not take a long time to do; the maximum time limit for the short film was 3 minutes and you only have to write around 1000 words for the final essay. The deadline for the final essay was set after the final exam period, so you could finish your exams then write the essay afterwards.
